title: Miso-Glazed Eggplant (Nasu Dengaku)
description: A classic Japanese small-plate featuring tender, broiled eggplant brushed with a savory-sweet miso glaze. The eggplant is soft and smoky while the glaze adds umami, mirin sweetness and a hint of sesame for balance.

ingredients.notes: halved lengthwise, scored crosswise in the flesh without cutting through skin
or yellow miso for slightly stronger flavor
use gluten-free tamari if avoiding wheat

ingredients.display_name: neutral oil (vegetable or canola) for brushing
ingredients.notes: for roasting or pan-searing the eggplant
add small amount if glaze feels too thick

ingredients.display_name: scallions (green parts), thinly sliced for garnish
ingredients.notes: white parts can be reserved for other uses

steps.text: Preheat the broiler to high and position a rack 6 inches from the heat source; alternatively, preheat oven to 425°F (220°C) for roasting. Line a baking sheet with foil for easy cleanup.
Prepare the eggplants: halve each eggplant lengthwise, trim the stem, and score the flesh in a crosshatch pattern without cutting through the skin. Lightly brush the cut surfaces with neutral oil.

Cook the eggplants: place cut-side down on the baking sheet and broil until the flesh is well browned and very tender when pierced with a fork, about 8–10 minutes. If roasting, cook cut-side down for 20–25 minutes until soft and charred at the edges.

While the eggplants cook, make the miso glaze: whisk together miso, mirin, sake, sugar, soy sauce and sesame oil in a small bowl until smooth; if too thick, add a small amount of water to reach a spreadable consistency.
Turn the broiler to high if needed. Remove the eggplants from the oven and flip them cut-side up. Spoon or brush the miso glaze evenly over the flesh of each eggplant half in a thin layer.

Broil the glazed eggplants until the miso glaze is bubbling and starting to brown and caramelize, about 3–4 minutes — watch closely to avoid burning. If using oven, switch to high broil for the final 3–4 minutes or bake at 425°F until glaze bubbles.
Remove from heat, let rest briefly, then garnish with sliced scallions and toasted sesame seeds. Serve warm as a side or small plate.
